text:
Nate’s Conjecture: Connecting Circles to Cylinders

In Problem 2.1 we folded identical sheets of a paper to form right prisms and explored which prism had the most volume. Nate noticed that as the number of sides of the prism increased its shape became more circular. So, he made a cylinder and claimed it has the most volume.

Recall that a cylinder, such as a soup can or a barrel, is like a prism with circles for top and bottom bases. Strategies for making and measuring prisms are helpful guides to reasoning about cylinders.

The size and shape of every cylinder is set by two measurements—the height of the cylinder and either the radius or diameter of its circular base. These measurements are called the dimensions of the figure.
To know if Nate’s claim is correct, we can think about “filling” cylinders the same way we filled prisms in Problem 2.1.
